results.title: Green Fingers: Pest and Disease Control
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this is an archival film and contemporary advice should be sought when handling chemicals and poisons.

‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Pest and Disease Control’, Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to use agricultural sprays on a rose garden at Burnley Gardens.

Diseases described include black spot, aphids and powdery mildew. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: The Australian Alps: Mirka's Palace of Dreams (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: David Greig, David Morgan and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
This program is the last in a series of six documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia. Mirka Mora is an eccentric artist, French by birth, who had never before ventured into the wilderness nor slept in a tent. Along with Tim McCartney Snape, the first Australian ever to reach the summit of Mt. Everest, and a Nepalese Sherpa, she travels into the Kosciusko wilderness. Mirka’s unique and expressive personality helps viewers see and experience this wilderness from an artist’s perspective.
results.title_for_label: The Australian Alps: Mirka’s Palace of Dreams (Captioned)
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig, David Morgan and Kestrel Film Productions

results.title: Daintree: The Vanishing Rainforest (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Danae Gunn, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
A child returns from the future, a time when forests no longer exist and we see the rainforest and its most unusual inhabitants through her eyes. She grows to love the forest and cannot understand some of the things she sees happening. An imaginative and fascinating story which emphasises the delicate balance of nature, and how easily it can be destroyed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Danae Gunn, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions

results.title: Canning Vegetables
results.brief_description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.
results.description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.
description_for_label: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.

results.title: South West Tasmania: The Gliders (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Catherine Millar, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
The sheer challenge of remote wilderness is shown in this spectacular program of a group’s arduous trek up Federation Peak with the aim of hang gliding from the top. Young and old take part in the trek and viewers share in the thoughts, inspiration and differing goals of the group.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Catherine Millar, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions

results.title: Kimberley: Wandjina country
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Part three of a series of six documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia. Belinda Wright and Stanley Breeden are naturalists and photographers who work for the National Geographic Society. As they become fascinated with the “Wandjina” rock paintings, the viewer also gains some insight into the deep, spiritual relationship the Aboriginal people have with the land. A Teacher’s guide accompanies the video.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions

results.title: Kakadu: Land of the Crocodile
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Wilderness is increasingly recognised as a scarce and vital commodity worldwide. In this video, Part 2 in a series of 6 documentaries, Val Plumwood, environmental philosopher and writer returns to Kakadu, where she was the victim of a terrible crocodile attack. Set against the steamy, intensely beautiful, backdrop of Kakadu National Park viewers share her thoughts on wilderness and wildlife. Accompanied by a Teacher’s Guide.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)

results.title: Green Fingers: Weed Control
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Weed Control’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to control weeds in the home garden. Cantrill shows a range of methods for managing weeds, including hoeing, mulching and herbicides, accompanied by a narrator who explains the benefits and correct techniques of each method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.
results.description: Green Fingers was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Weed Control’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to control weeds in the home garden. Cantrill shows a range of methods for managing weeds, including hoeing, mulching and herbicides, accompanied by a narrator who explains the benefits and correct techniques of each method. The episodes of Green Fingers are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of Sow What, Better Homes and Gardens, and Gardening Australia.
